results.title: Hacknet
results.creator_credit: Team Fractal Alligator and Fellow Traveller
results.brief_description: Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

constellations_primary.name: Hack the planet
constellations_primary.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

results.description:
If you’ve ever wanted to know what hacking is really like, Hacknet is the game for you. Simulating a true-to-life terminal environment, the game tasks the player with using computer commands similar to what a real hacker would use. These skills are put to use solving the murder of a character named Bit, who contacts the player through a computer program initiated after their death.

Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

results.title: Habitat UK 76
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Michael Birkett and Anthony Wilkinson
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems of redevelopment of cities. Emphasises that circumstances forever change and uses Birmingham as an example that single, large-scale comprehensive approaches to planning may not be the best approach.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Central Office of Information, Michael Birkett and Anthony Wilkinson

results.title: Habitat
results.creator_credit: United Nations Films and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Human habitat is any place where humans live. In the past most habitats were rural and posed relatively simple problems. At the moment, the human race is posing entirely new, and often complex problems. This film describes some of these problems and suggests some solutions

results.title: Habit Patterns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
It’s a little late for tears, isn’t it Barabara? Says the brutal narrator at the beginning of the film. This instructional piece, as the title suggests, is for developing good habits. At the start of the film, Barbara stands by the closed door of her bedroom, weeping pitifully. She has bad habits, and this film sends her to social hell as we flash-back to the beginning of her day. She is sloppy and unorganised, sleeps in, and is generally discourteous. All the examples of problems caused by her bad habits in this film are social blunders, which get worse as the film progresses. The narrator is unforgiving: “How easy it is not to be invited again.” and “how quickly you can be left out of the crowd”. This film is more about conformity than keeping good habits.

results.title: H.R. Pufnstuf: The wheely bird
results.brief_description: Jimmy, his magic flute Freddy and best friend H.R. Pufnstuf have to battle the evil Witchiepoo. In this episode, Jimmy and Pufnstuf use a bird-shaped “Trojan Horse” as a trick in order to enter Witchiepoo’s castle to recover the stolen Golden Flute Freddie.
results.description: Jimmy, his magic flute Freddy and best friend H.R. Pufnstuf have to battle the evil Witchiepoo. In this episode, Jimmy and Pufnstuf use a bird-shaped “Trojan Horse” as a trick in order to enter Witchiepoo’s castle to recover the stolen Golden Flute Freddie.

results.title: H.R. Pufnstuf: the magic path
results.brief_description: On a walk through the forest, Jimmy and his magic flute Freddy are lured away by Witchiepoo to Living Island. They remain trapped when Witchiepoo makes the Magic Path disappear and Jimmy must rely on the resources and loyalty of his best friend H.R. Pufnstuf to get him out of trouble.
